build-flow-test-aggregator.excerpt: h2. Overview Build Flow Test Aggregator is the simplest way to aggregate test results from builds started dynamically by the build flow job. It's a post-build step that only shows up for build flow projects. Normally to aggregate test results Jenkins has to "understand" the upstream - downstream dependencies between jobs. This can be achieved by generating an artifact in job1 and fingerprinting that archive from all the downstream jobs. But even then you'd have to have a separate job where you aggregate test results, which is not convenient. Build Flow Test Aggregator simply loops over all of the builds scheduled by a flow run and retrieves and aggregates test results if there are any. The test results will be available just like any other test results, it will show aggregated results and statistics, with links to each individual test for further inspection: !http://cl.ly/image/2S1k221G1k0W/Image%202014-11-07%20at%201.37.40%20pm.png|border=1!

cloudbees-cloud-backup.excerpt:
CloudBees Free Plugin
This plugin simplifies backing up Jenkins and backs them to the cloud. Adminsitrators can now save hours by easily backing up and recovering from crashes using the backup. Users can easily create a new job type called "Backup" and back up build records, job and system configurations. The backups are stored on a CloudBees DEV@cloud server and the plugin requires a CloudBees account. The plugin offers mutliple retention policies for the records such as keeping the last 'n' records, keep all backups or an exponential decay algorithm to save space.

cloudbees-cloud-backup.title: CloudBees Back-up Cloud Plugin

JEBC has 20\+ plugins that address issues in enterprise installations. Plugins include folders, validate merges, templates, roles-based access control, backup plugins and others (complete list). Additionally, you can use the HA component to make Jenkins highly available. *Note:* As part of the installation process, you will require a valid license to use the CloudBees Enterprise plugins. An evaluation license can be requested by filling a form on CloudBees website. Once the evaluation license expires, you must either obtain a full license OR uninstall the plugins requiring such a license.

cloudbees-template.excerpt:
Jenkins Enterprise by CloudBees Plugin
This plugin captures "sameness of jobs". Adminstratores can define templates of jobs & builders. Teams can instantiate new jobs based on the template. A change to a template automatically is reflected on all jobs, thus saving hours in configuration. Administrators can talk in the domain-specific language of users and only expose those configuration options that make "sense" in the users environment rather than exposing the user to the entire job configuration screen. This reduces potential errors by users when defining jobs.Another way to look at this is that it lets you write rudimentary plugins without coding in Java.

cloudbees-template.title: CloudBees Template Plugin

Administrators easily setup an Update Center by adding a new job type called "Update Center" and uploading the right artifacts.

nectar-rbac.excerpt:
Jenkins Enterprise by CloudBees Plugin
The Role Based Access Control plugin gives a Jenkins administrator the ability to define various security roles that will apply to the system they administer. Once roles have been defined the Jenkins administrator can assign those roles to groups of users. The assignment of roles can take place either at the global level, or limited to specific objects within the system. And, additionally, the Jenkins administrator can even delegate the management of groups for specific objects to specific users.

The plugin currently supports POM, SBT, and Build.scala. SemanticVersioning uses the values parsed from the build definition files in conjunction with the {color}Jenkins{color:#333333} build number to create a {color}Semantic Versioning{color:#333333} string. The string is stored in an build-environment variable (name is configurable). Additionally the{color} Semantic Versioning{color:#333333} string is written to a file in the Artifact directory.{color} {color:#333333}The second part of the plugin adds a column to the Dashboard that displays the {color}Semantic Versioning{color:#333333} string from the most recent successful build.{color}"
